history.content:
Just some general stuff (can be vague) based on my experience:

1. Fundamental CS, lots of math and statistics. Maybe get a PhD if you are interested in a special area.

2.

- Get smarter. Actually try to understand concepts and don't BS your homeworks, etc. The interview questions can be/are hard.

- Different companies do different things and have (drastically) different interview styles. Do your research beforehand.

- Also, be active in job hunting. A lot of the programs are geared towards schools like Harvard/MIT, so they won't reach out to you most likely.

- Non tier1 companies are not that tough to get in (and they pay less than top tech companies).

3.

- With just a bachelors degree, you will most likely end up as a dev or a trader. Most "quant" positions require a graduate degree unless you can prove yourself really well. I can't say for all companies, but I've seen a lot of companies claim they allow "hybrids" but they don't actually get treated as well as the real "quants".

- You will have long working hours (depends on the company, do your research).

- You might get located in Chicago or Europe/Asia w/o having a choice.

- If you are going for the money, don't expect too much right after college. I'd say the starting compensation packages at top tech companies and tier1 quant houses are similar. The growth as a quant is better, but not exceptionally/astronomically unless you are a rockstar (which applies everywhere).

- There are lots of online resources. Use them wisely.

- There are constantly new regulations and restrictions in trading.

- Tech giants hire hundreds of interns and new employees. Quant houses hire only a couple dozen max.

- Going from quant to tech isn't that hard if you ever change your mind :)

- Having said everything above, the industry is fun and rewarding!

children.subject: If you don't want to post your email that's fine. Can you email me at helloworld414243@gmail.com? I really want to become a quant and your advice is superb.
Student Answerer: Are you a quant? Can I email you?
4.0 GPA and dozens of A+. This is how I passed through the resume round. Then you need some real stuff in your head: math+cs+stats.

Not a quant but have been through quant interviews. Get really good at probability/statistics/counting/algo design. Like  you could ace 2000 point jeopardy question level good. Interview a lot, and do some mock interviews for jane street and similar firms

history.content:
Hi everyone,

I am here to seek your advice on becoming a quant (quantitative analyst). I am a CS major. I know I'm really interested in the areas quants study, but I've never interned/worked in a quant firm, like many of you have.

1. What skills do I need to be a quant? Required + must-have

2. What should I do over the next 3 years at Cal to help me get this job (eg, internships, etc)?

3. What must I keep in mind? Anything else?

If you post your email below, I will email you for further questions. 

I really appreciate you guys taking your time out and answering my question. It means a lot to me that you'd do that for some random Cal student.
history.subject: How to become a quant?
